import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.e8d46563:

loan_data.head()
source.5fd1b6c6:
sns.set(font_scale=1.1)
correlation_train = loan_data.corr()
mask = np.triu(correlation_train.corr())
plt.figure(figsize=(20, 7))
sns.heatmap(correlation_train,
            annot=True,
            fmt='.1f',
            cmap='coolwarm',
            square=True,
            mask=mask,
            linewidths=1,
            cbar=False)

plt.show()

source.31971ea1:
# Kurtosis is a statistical measure that defines how heavily the tails of a distribution differ from the tails of a 
# normal distribution. In other words, kurtosis identifies whether the tails of a given distribution contain extreme 
# values.
source.0194b4e6:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=1, ncols=2, figsize=(20, 6))
sns.kdeplot(loan_data[loan_data["Loan_Status"] == "Y"]["ApplicantIncome"], shade=True,label="Loan Accepeted",ax=ax[0])
sns.kdeplot(loan_data[loan_data["Loan_Status"] == "N"]["ApplicantIncome"], shade=True,label="Loan Rejected",ax=ax[0])
sns.boxplot(y=loan_data["ApplicantIncome"], x=loan_data["Loan_Status"])
source.90f5fd44:
print("Loan Accepted")
print("Skewness :  ", stat.skew(loan_data[loan_data["Loan_Status"] == 'Y']["ApplicantIncome"]))
print("Kurtosis :  ", stat.kurtosis(loan_data[loan_data["Loan_Status"] == 'Y']["ApplicantIncome"]))
print("*"*60)
print("Loan Rejected")
print("Skewness :  ", stat.skew(loan_data[loan_data["Loan_Status"] == 'N']["ApplicantIncome"]))

source.daa95cdb: #### Q> Relation between ApplicantIncome vs CoapplicantIncome ?
source.302c2075: It seems like there is 10% higher chance of getting loan when a candidate is married.
source.0fc28439: Although data is highly imbalanced but it does provide a significant seperation between getting a loan and not getting a loan.
source.9fe8032f: An inverse relation is been seen i.e. if 'ApplicantIncome' is high 'CoapplicantIncome' is low and vice-versa.
source.d60c7f00:
Ans> Clearly we can observe three different things:
1> An applicant asking for high loan amount but having low income will have hard time getting loan e.g. (250, 30000) and (350, 80000) where (LoanAmount, ApplicantIncome)

2> An applicant asking for low loan amount but having comparitvely high income will be easily getting loan e.g. (120, 40000) and (150, 390000)

3> Apart from that it almost follow a straight line pattern
source.8fbd9fba: #### Q> What is the relation between 'LoanAmount', 'ApplicantIncome' and 'LoanStatus' ?
source.4550c2f6: LoanAmount and ApplicantIncome are highly linearly correlated (see confusion matrix at top)
source.733ca982:
OBSERVATION:
1> 81% applicant's are male (Highly unbalanced)
2> 67% female and 69% male gets the loan (Right Graph)
3> Of all the people who got the loan 81% are male, (but since this is because of imbalance in data so this statistics is Useless)
source.8fc4282f: ### If you like my work , plz do upvote and leave all your doubts to the comment section :)
source.19e36703: #### Q> Does hight earning people ask for high amount loan ?
source.d1ba6fef:
Q> Does higher Loan Amount mean higher chance of loan rejection ?
Ans> Loan Amount alone does not provide enough significance for rejection of an applicant request for loan, e.g. a person asking for higher loan amount and having good credit history, income, co-applicant income etc. has higher chance of getting loan compared to a person asking for low loan amount and having poor credit history, low income etc.
source.460b27ee: According to left graph we might assume that male candidate have higher chance of getting loan but this will be mis-interpretation since the actual reason for that graph to look like that is the Imbalance in male and female candidates.
source.7e9a2646:
According to the graph we may be tempted to say that there is a large significance between Education and Loan Status
but when looked using numerical percpective we conclude that there is only about 10% increase in chance of getting Loan if you are graduate.
source.359d8f6c:
OBSERVATIONS:
1> 65% applicant's are married (Imbalanced)
2> A married applicant has 72% chance of getting loan wheras 63% for unmarried
3> 68% applicant's who got the loan where married and 58% applicant who didn't got the loan where married
source.95c854e4: Ans> It does seems to follow the trend that high Imcome people apply for high amount loan with few aseption in data.
